translation.displayName: Morbid (severe) obesity due to excess calories
Body mass index (BMI) 70 or greater, adult

tr.td: Title: OSA, OHS, RLS, insomnia, tobacco use, DOE

Impression and Plan
Impression:
1. Obstructive sleep apnea with obesity hypoventilation syndrome: We will need to get a current sleep study for the patient to be able to get a new CPAP. We will also need to evaluate her oxygen saturation during the sleep study and determine if she needs supplemental oxygen and at what level.
2. Chronic insomnia: The patient's insomnia started after her grandmother's death. In talking to her in the office, she began crying. She has not processed her grief for this loss. She may benefit from counseling. Her untreated OSA and probable nocturnal hypoxemia also affect her inability to initiate sleep.
3. Restless leg syndrome: The patient has symptoms every night. She is currently working with her primary provider to treat her anemia. She has just started iron in the last month. I have given her a brochure about restless leg syndrome and treatment options. Will need to recheck her ferritin after she has been treated with iron.
4. Tobacco use: Talk to the patient about smoking cessation. It appears she has tried multiple treatment plans and none of them have been successful. I have urged her to try one more time and see if she can stop before she has surgery.
5. Dyspnea on exertion: Most likely related to her super morbid obesity. Will need to get complete PFTs on next office visit.
6. Super morbid obesity: BMI 86. The patient tells me that she has lost 50 pounds and she is trying to lose more. She may eventually need to have bariatric surgery to help her in this effort.
7. Hypertension
8. Diabetes mellitus
9. Mild pulmonary hypertension on echocardiogram
10. Depression: Patient has clearly not processed the death of 3 relatives including grandmother, mother and father. She will probably need counseling to help her with this to improve her life.
Plan:
1. Polysomnogram with supplemental oxygen as needed to keep oxygen saturation above 88%.
2. Complete PFTs on next office visit
3. Continue weight loss efforts
4. Patient was cautioned not to drive if drowsy.
5. Return to office in 2-3 months after the sleep study
Jeremy Blackburn APRN
CC: Carla Robertson, APRN

paragraph.content: Monitoring Your Sleep: Sleep Lab Testing

text.paragraph:
Monitoring Your Sleep: Sleep Lab Testing
During a sleep study, sensors track and record body functions.
Checking your sleep during a nighttime sleep study is often the only way to find out if you have conditions such as sleep apnea or other sleep problems. A sleep study records how your lungs, heart, brain, and other parts of your body function while youre asleep. Its painless, risk-free, and in most cases takesa single,full night.
Testing in a sleep clinic
If you spend the night in a sleep clinic, you will have a private bedroom. A technician will attach many sensors to your body, then go into another room. As you sleep, your heart rate, breathing, oxygen level, brain activity, and other functions will be tracked. A microphone and video camera will record your breathing sounds and body movements. The technician will keep watch nearby. If you need an air pressure device to help you breathe, one will be available.
Tips for testing in a sleep lab
Before your sleep study, bathe and wash your hair. Dont use conditioners, oils, or makeup.
Stick to your normal routine. If you usually drink alcohol, exercise, or take medicine before bed, ask your healthcare provider whether you should do so the night of your study. Most people who have a sleep study done should take all of their medicines as they typically would at home.But it is best to check with your healthcare provider to confirm.
Bring your toothbrush, sleepwear, pillow, something to read, and anything else that will help you sleep well.
Before the testing starts, feel free to ask the technician any questions you may have.
Getting the results
The results of your sleep study need to be scored and interpreted. Once this is done, your healthcare providerwill discuss the findings with you. The sleep study results will show whether you have sleep apnea or another sleep disorder. It can also tell how severe the apnea is. The findings help your healthcare providerknow which treatment or treatments may be the right ones for you.
